title: NIPS_2016_80_abs

sentences.text: Fast algorithms for nearest neighbor -LRB- NN -RRB- search have in large part focused on 2 distance .
Here we develop an approach for 1 distance that begins with an explicit and exactly distance-preserving embedding of the points into 2 2 .
We show how this can efficiently be combined with random-projection based methods for 2 NN search , such as locality-sensitive hashing -LRB- LSH -RRB- or random projection trees .
We rigorously establish the correctness of the methodology and show by experimentation using LSH that it is competitive in practice with available alternatives .

summary: Fast algorithms for nearest neighbor -LRB- NN -RRB- search have in large part focused on 2 distance . Here we develop an approach for 1 distance that begins with an explicit and exactly distance-preserving embedding of the points into 2 2 . We show how this can efficiently be combined with random-projection based methods for 2 NN search , such as locality-sensitive hashing -LRB- LSH -RRB- or random projection trees . We rigorously establish the correctness of the methodology and show by experimentation using LSH that it is competitive in practice with available alternatives .
kg2text: The 2 NN search develops an approach for 1 distance, which begins with an explicit and exactly distance-preserving embedding. This approach is part of a broader category that includes fast algorithms for nearest neighbor and the nearest neighbor algorithm itself, both of which focus on the 2 distance metric. Random-projection based methods are combined with 2 NN search and are utilized for this search method. Additionally, locality-sensitive hashing (LSH) plays a significant role in experimentation using LSH, which demonstrates the correctness of the methodology. LSH is a broader term that encompasses locality-sensitive hashing techniques. The explicit and exactly distance-preserving embedding is also combined with random-projection based methods, which are further combined with random projection trees. Overall, these methodologies and techniques contribute to efficient nearest neighbor searches while preserving the necessary distance metrics.

Fast algorithms for nearest neighbor are a subset of algorithms that focus on efficiently identifying the closest points in a dataset. These algorithms utilize techniques such as explicit and exactly distance-preserving embedding, which embeds points into a higher-dimensional space while maintaining their distances. Within the realm of distance metrics, 1 distance, which is based on the Manhattan distance, is a broader term under the general concept of distance. Additionally, random projection trees and locality-sensitive hashing (LSH) are also categorized as algorithms that facilitate nearest neighbor searches. LSH, in particular, is a method that enables probabilistic dimension reduction, allowing for efficient similarity searches. The methodology developed in this context establishes the correctness of the methodology, ensuring its reliability. Furthermore, experimentation using LSH is a practical evaluation that falls under the broader category of experimentation, which is competitive in practice with available alternatives. Overall, these algorithms and methodologies are interconnected, with each contributing to the advancement of nearest neighbor search techniques.
